BIG MEET AT HOMEWOOD

HOPKINS SHUTS OUT STEVENS

VARSITY BALL TEAM WINS

THE VOTE WAS CLOSE

The South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association Will Hold Its Championship
Events at Homewood.

Hobokenites No Match for Fast Black
and Blue Twelve Championship
Prospects Brighter for Hopkins.

Down Western Maryland in Easy Game.
Porter and Ober Star Promising
Outlook for State Championship.

Student Mass-Meetirg Decided to Uphold
the Policy of the Athletic Board.
Sentiment Divided.

More than one hundred star athletes from the leading universities
and colleges of the South will assemble at Homewood on Friday
and Saturday, May 3 and 4, for
the first championship track and
field meet of the newly organized
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association.
Everything indicates that the
meet will be the biggest thing in
the way of track athletics that has
ever come off in Baltimore. All
the contestants are picked men,
some of whom are coming all the
way' from North Carolina. None
of the events will be one-sided, as
the entries in the various events are
very well balanced.
The preliminaries of all the
events, except the one and two
mile runs, will be held on Friday
afternoon. The best five men in
each event will qualify for the
finals, which will be run off Saturday afternoon before the Swarthmore lacrosse game.
*
The institutions forming the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association are: Johns Hopkins University, Washington and Lee University, Georgetown University,
University of North Carolina, Richmond College, Agricultural and
Mechanical College of North Carolina, Virginia Polytechnic Institute
and Wake Forest College.
With the exception of Wake Forest College they have all entered
strong track and field teams. The
Wake Forest athletes want to
enter, but will probably be prevented by their examinations, which begin this week.
Handsome medals have been
ordered by the Hopkins committee
in charge of arranging the meet.
The Hopkins committee has done
everything in its power to make
the meet as big a success as po'•
sible. Special accommodations are
being arranged by the Homewood
committee for the use of the visitors, as the Hopkins clubhouse will
not be big enough to accommodate
them and the Swarthmore lacrosse
team also. Certain sections of the
grandstand will be reserved, and
in response to a number of requests
Spaces along the finish of the mo
and 220-yard straightaway have
been reserved for automobiles.
The reserved seats and automobile
reservations are on sale at Albaug-h's.
The FIopkins list of entries in
the meet will be an exceptionally
large one. Coaches England and

Hoboken, N. J., April 27.—True
championship form was displayed
by the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
when it not only defeated but completely shut out the Stevens Institute twelve this afternoon at Castle
Point Field by the score of 8 to o.
The work of the Baltimore team
was practically perfect in every department of the game. The strong
Hopkins defense proved invulnerable, and the attack, especially during the latter part of the second
half, kept the ball in the vicinity
of the Stevens goal nearly all the
time.
For the first ten minutes after the
game began, the play was fairly
even. The Hopkins players had
possession of the ball more than
their opponents, but were unable
to get within striking distance of
the Stevens net. Easter scored the
.first tally for the visitors and followed it up with two more before
the/half was over. Although the
field was in a very soggy condition and there were intermittent
showers, full 35 - minute halves
were played.
Troxeil, the outhome of the visitors, started the scoring in the second period of play. Captain Gail
of Hopkins then shot four goals in
'close succession in the latter part
of the half. The Johns Hopkins
attack was beautiful to watch. The
Baltimoreans moved against the
Stevens goal in perfect unison.
They looked over the situation carefully, and worked the extra man
play whenever there was an opportunity.
The lineup was as follows:

In a game marked by the heavy
hitting of the 'varsity and the costly
errors of their opponents, the ball
team won their first victory over
a local college by.defeating Western
Maryland at Homewood on Saturday by a score of 8 to 2. Spectacular work by the outfield and by Pete
Porter at third was largely responsible for the small tally of the visitors. Porter, in addition to accepting several difficult chances, with
only one slip-up, managed to net
four hits out of five times at .bat,
but Ober's catch of Treisler's long
fly in .the third inning was undoubt(.‘dly the most spectacular play of
the game. Starting at the first
crack of the bat for a ball which,
at first glance, looked good for a
home run, he literally dove for the
elusive sphere, fell, turned a complete somersault, but came up
smilingly with the ball in his glove.
The rOoters, ably led by Spring
Cheer Teacher George Gillet, gave
him a rousing cheer. The practice gotten by playing such teams
as Harvard, Yale, Princeton or
Georgetown was evident whenever
the team got in a hole. Pieper's
headwork and pitching at such times
was remarkable.
Western Maryland's .rightfielder,
Graefe, redeemed several costly
errors by clouting out a homer over
the rightfield fence, which, however, could have been easily caught
had the rightfield been longer.
Better form was shown Saturday
than in any game this season, only
three errors being chalked up for
the 'varsity, and these only came
from the miserable weather conditions.

By a bare majority those present
at the mass-meeting on Thursday
decided not to take any action with
regard to the "new athletic policies" which, when published in THE
NEWS-LETTER, arcused Such a s _orm
of protest. Resolutions, prepared
by Mr. J. S. Dickinson at the request of the Student _Council, and
offered by him, were voted down,
after they were amended. These
resolutions were as follows:
Resolved, That the Athletic Board,
by not confining itself in its recent
announcement of policies to those matters which, as true matters of policy,
come within its province, and by undertaking to effect a fundamental alteration in the distribution of powers
between the various elements of our
athletic organization—students, alumni
and faculty—has exceeded the limits
of its constitutional authority,
Resolved, Moreover, that the alterations in the fundamental distribution
of powers which it effe2ts, and
which confer on representatives of the
faculty not merely the.veto power that
is their just and undisputed right, but
in addition a minute and all-pervading
power of direction and management,
are unnecessary, are insulting, and
tend to debase sport and .to commercialize athletics.

These resolutions were offered to
start the discussion. Dr. R. V. D.
Magoffin, the faculty representative
on the Athletic Board, was the first
speaker, and made a thirty-five minute address. Mr. Dickinson's resolutions applied to Sections I I to 14
of the "policies." Concerning these
Dr. Magoffin said that the language
was unfortunate, and that they
didn't mean what they said. The
policies in question are as follows:
11. The director of the gymnasium,
by reason of his position, is the only
absolute head of athletics. He may
call into consultation anyone he desires, but the authority for the final
decision rests with him.
12. Any new athletic policy or meetings for the discussion of athletic policy, held either by students or alumni,
should be brought before the director
of tile gymnasium.
13. The graduate manager should report to the director of the gymnasium
at least weekly as to the conduct of
his office.
14. Under the director of the gymnasium the Athletic Board is Lae final
authority in all branches of athletics:
Individual members of the board may
inquire into any action taken during
the interim of the board meetings, but
they have no authority, except through
the graduate manager or the director
of the gymnasium.
•

Other speakers were Messrs.
Dickinson, Rogers, Fulton, Burgan,
Elicott, Gillet and Getz. Mr. Price
left the chair and spoke in favor of
the resolutions. He pointed out

BALTIMORE, MD., APR. 29, 1912
The Result.

The student mass-meeting has decided to uphold the policy of the
Athletic Board. The vote was close,
showing that Trig NEWS-LETTER
was• right in feeling that sentiment
was divided. That the resolution
was defeated has not changed the
mind of a single member of THE
NEWS-LETTER Board. We still feel
that the Athletic Board made a mistake, and assumed unwarranted
powers in setting forth the policy.
Nevertheless, Tint NEWS-LETTER
is satisfied. The students have had
an opportunity to express their opinion of the policy and they have done
so. Neither of the two parties
which the issue called into being
has any reason to claim victory.
The Athletic Board was not embarrassed by any censure of the policy
which it had seen fit to adopt; but.
on the other hand, that -policy was
defended only on the ground that
it aid not mean all that it said, and
the vote of confidence which was passed was given only in the belief that the obnoxious eleventh,
twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth
articles of the policy would not be
construed according to the letter.
We have confidence enough in the
man upon whim the objectionable
powers are conferred to believe
that he will not abuse them ; but
we sincerely hope that the Athletic
Board, which has acknowledged
through its representative at the
meeting that the policies are expressed in unfortunate terms, will,
at an early date, take steps to revise them.

I have often gone to a lacrosse
game myself, and wondered how
the center ever lasted through the
two halves. The last game—the
one with Carlisle—carried me beyond the "wonderipg" point. I decided to settle the question once for
all, and to publish the results for
the benefit of the ages! [Hurrah!]
I knew that the track of the center would not be straight by any
means. In fact, I found later that
it was like the crookedness of three
or four shafts of lightning and several shooting stars linked together.
I determined to reckon the distance
by half lengths of the field. The
half length was the best unit of
measurement, because the center
starts from the middle of the field.
Of course, each separate half length
had to be estimated, but on the
whole I did it carefully, and the results should be reasonably correct.
I watched both the Indian and
Hopkins centers., The . outcome of
the count astonished me. First Half—Hopkins center ran
717
2 (half lengths of field). Indian center ran 80 (half lengths of
field).
Second Half—Hopkins center ran
70 (half lengths of field). Indian
centers—they had three—(90 half
lengths of field).
Whole Game—Hopkins center,
14.072 (half lengths of field). Indian centers, 170 (half lengths of
field).
A half length of the field is 65
yards. Therefore, the Hopkins center ran 14072x65=9,13272 yards,
or 5 miles and 33272 yards (that is,
about 575 miles).
The Indian centers ran 170x65.7--11,050 yards, or 6 miles and 490
yards (that is, about 67. miles).
Me for the trolley car!
Yours sincerely,
MATHEMATICUS INSPIRATICUS.
April 20, 1912.
I have long promised myself the
pleasure of writing and offering to
THF, NEWS-LETTER a sort of scientific study of athletics at Johns
Hopkins from the standpoint of the
"dub," in which I should point out
just how little chance the unmuscular undergraduate has of getting
ally fun and exercise out of our
fine athletic equipments:. and in
which I should perhaps offer a few
simple ideas, such as will suggest
themselves to anyone, as to what
great things enthusiastic leadership
could do toward making our athletics help those vtho need help
most. I live in hope of seeing the
tinie when our athletic policy will
be expressed in one golden phrase:
"Every Hopkins man using Homewood Field."
Granted that this is my viewpoint, as it is that of many other
students and alumni, you can easily
see why we are inclined to rage at
this other athletic policy of recent
date. At a time when the best opportunity offers itself for an effort
to get the grandstand athlete down
on the field and track, and to give
his lungs better exercise than yelling for his favored mates, at -just
this time our athletics are to be

5
still more commercialized, dictators
are appointed, some folks mustn't
manage and some must—the Johns
Hopkins Athletic Company (Ltd.)
is incorporated!
We don't need new bosses, better
bosses, or more bosses; we need
somebody with enthusiasm and a
vision, who can get everybody,
muscles or no muscles, impatient to
go to Homewood of an afternoon,
to enjoy an hour or two of sport
under the Black and Blue. He
will be harder to find than .a new
president. Until he conies student
management of student activities is
the only thing which can keep us
out of the slough of Athletic indifference.
GEORGE W. CORNER, 3d, '09.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 29, 1912.

Rhodes Scholarships.
The announcement has recently
reached the University that the
next examinations for the Rhodes
Scholarship will be held here in October, 1912. Two scholarships are
awarded to residents of Maryland,
or students in the state, and are for
three years' residence at Oxford
University. Their value is $1,5oo
per year. The requirements for
eligibility are that a man must be
above 19 and under 25 years old.
He must have finished his sophomore year in college, and he must
be unmarried.
The Rhodes Scholarship examinations are not competitive, but
qualifying, for the award is not
made upon scholarship alone. The
papers set are the regular Oxford
entrance requirements, or "Responsiors," and include arithmetic,
elementary geometry or algebra, elementary Latin and elementary
Greek. A special rule is made that
A:merican students may be eligible
for the scholarship without taking
the Greek examination, but if
awarded the scholarship, they must
study Greek before they are able to
enter Oxford University.
When the candidates have passed
the qualifying . examinations and
award is made upon the basis of
general scholarship one-third, of
athletic ability one-third, and of
general character one-third,

BIG MEET AT HOMEWOOD

HOPKINS SHUTS OUT STEVENS

VARSITY BALL TEAM WINS

THE VOTE WAS CLOSE

The South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association Will Hold Its Championship
Events at Homewood.

Hobokenites No Match for Fast Black
and Blue Twelve Championship
Prospects Brighter for Hopkins.

Down Western Maryland in Easy Game.
Porter and Ober Star Promising
Outlook for State Championship.

Student Mass-Meetirg Decided to Uphold
the Policy of the Athletic Board.
Sentiment Divided.

More than one hundred star athletes from the leading universities
and colleges of the South will assemble at Homewood on Friday
and Saturday, May 3 and 4, for
the first championship track and
field meet of the newly organized
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association.
Everything indicates that the
meet will be the biggest thing in
the way of track athletics that has
ever come off in Baltimore. All
the contestants are picked men,
some of whom are coming all the
way' from North Carolina. None
of the events will be one-sided, as
the entries in the various events are
very well balanced.
The preliminaries of all the
events, except the one and two
mile runs, will be held on Friday
afternoon. The best five men in
each event will qualify for the
finals, which will be run off Saturday afternoon before the Swarthmore lacrosse game.
*
The institutions forming the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Association are: Johns Hopkins University, Washington and Lee University, Georgetown University,
University of North Carolina, Richmond College, Agricultural and
Mechanical College of North Carolina, Virginia Polytechnic Institute
and Wake Forest College.
With the exception of Wake Forest College they have all entered
strong track and field teams. The
Wake Forest athletes want to
enter, but will probably be prevented by their examinations, which begin this week.
Handsome medals have been
ordered by the Hopkins committee
in charge of arranging the meet.
The Hopkins committee has done
everything in its power to make
the meet as big a success as po'•
sible. Special accommodations are
being arranged by the Homewood
committee for the use of the visitors, as the Hopkins clubhouse will
not be big enough to accommodate
them and the Swarthmore lacrosse
team also. Certain sections of the
grandstand will be reserved, and
in response to a number of requests
Spaces along the finish of the mo
and 220-yard straightaway have
been reserved for automobiles.
The reserved seats and automobile
reservations are on sale at Albaug-h's.
The FIopkins list of entries in
the meet will be an exceptionally
large one. Coaches England and

Hoboken, N. J., April 27.—True
championship form was displayed
by the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
when it not only defeated but completely shut out the Stevens Institute twelve this afternoon at Castle
Point Field by the score of 8 to o.
The work of the Baltimore team
was practically perfect in every department of the game. The strong
Hopkins defense proved invulnerable, and the attack, especially during the latter part of the second
half, kept the ball in the vicinity
of the Stevens goal nearly all the
time.
For the first ten minutes after the
game began, the play was fairly
even. The Hopkins players had
possession of the ball more than
their opponents, but were unable
to get within striking distance of
the Stevens net. Easter scored the
.first tally for the visitors and followed it up with two more before
the/half was over. Although the
field was in a very soggy condition and there were intermittent
showers, full 35 - minute halves
were played.
Troxeil, the outhome of the visitors, started the scoring in the second period of play. Captain Gail
of Hopkins then shot four goals in
'close succession in the latter part
of the half. The Johns Hopkins
attack was beautiful to watch. The
Baltimoreans moved against the
Stevens goal in perfect unison.
They looked over the situation carefully, and worked the extra man
play whenever there was an opportunity.
The lineup was as follows:

In a game marked by the heavy
hitting of the 'varsity and the costly
errors of their opponents, the ball
team won their first victory over
a local college by.defeating Western
Maryland at Homewood on Saturday by a score of 8 to 2. Spectacular work by the outfield and by Pete
Porter at third was largely responsible for the small tally of the visitors. Porter, in addition to accepting several difficult chances, with
only one slip-up, managed to net
four hits out of five times at .bat,
but Ober's catch of Treisler's long
fly in .the third inning was undoubt(.‘dly the most spectacular play of
the game. Starting at the first
crack of the bat for a ball which,
at first glance, looked good for a
home run, he literally dove for the
elusive sphere, fell, turned a complete somersault, but came up
smilingly with the ball in his glove.
The rOoters, ably led by Spring
Cheer Teacher George Gillet, gave
him a rousing cheer. The practice gotten by playing such teams
as Harvard, Yale, Princeton or
Georgetown was evident whenever
the team got in a hole. Pieper's
headwork and pitching at such times
was remarkable.
Western Maryland's .rightfielder,
Graefe, redeemed several costly
errors by clouting out a homer over
the rightfield fence, which, however, could have been easily caught
had the rightfield been longer.
Better form was shown Saturday
than in any game this season, only
three errors being chalked up for
the 'varsity, and these only came
from the miserable weather conditions.

By a bare majority those present
at the mass-meeting on Thursday
decided not to take any action with
regard to the "new athletic policies" which, when published in THE
NEWS-LETTER, arcused Such a s _orm
of protest. Resolutions, prepared
by Mr. J. S. Dickinson at the request of the Student _Council, and
offered by him, were voted down,
after they were amended. These
resolutions were as follows:
Resolved, That the Athletic Board,
by not confining itself in its recent
announcement of policies to those matters which, as true matters of policy,
come within its province, and by undertaking to effect a fundamental alteration in the distribution of powers
between the various elements of our
athletic organization—students, alumni
and faculty—has exceeded the limits
of its constitutional authority,
Resolved, Moreover, that the alterations in the fundamental distribution
of powers which it effe2ts, and
which confer on representatives of the
faculty not merely the.veto power that
is their just and undisputed right, but
in addition a minute and all-pervading
power of direction and management,
are unnecessary, are insulting, and
tend to debase sport and .to commercialize athletics.

These resolutions were offered to
start the discussion. Dr. R. V. D.
Magoffin, the faculty representative
on the Athletic Board, was the first
speaker, and made a thirty-five minute address. Mr. Dickinson's resolutions applied to Sections I I to 14
of the "policies." Concerning these
Dr. Magoffin said that the language
was unfortunate, and that they
didn't mean what they said. The
policies in question are as follows:
11. The director of the gymnasium,
by reason of his position, is the only
absolute head of athletics. He may
call into consultation anyone he desires, but the authority for the final
decision rests with him.
12. Any new athletic policy or meetings for the discussion of athletic policy, held either by students or alumni,
should be brought before the director
of tile gymnasium.
13. The graduate manager should report to the director of the gymnasium
at least weekly as to the conduct of
his office.
14. Under the director of the gymnasium the Athletic Board is Lae final
authority in all branches of athletics:
Individual members of the board may
inquire into any action taken during
the interim of the board meetings, but
they have no authority, except through
the graduate manager or the director
of the gymnasium.
•

Other speakers were Messrs.
Dickinson, Rogers, Fulton, Burgan,
Elicott, Gillet and Getz. Mr. Price
left the chair and spoke in favor of
the resolutions. He pointed out

BALTIMORE, MD., APR. 29, 1912
The Result.

The student mass-meeting has decided to uphold the policy of the
Athletic Board. The vote was close,
showing that Trig NEWS-LETTER
was• right in feeling that sentiment
was divided. That the resolution
was defeated has not changed the
mind of a single member of THE
NEWS-LETTER Board. We still feel
that the Athletic Board made a mistake, and assumed unwarranted
powers in setting forth the policy.
Nevertheless, Tint NEWS-LETTER
is satisfied. The students have had
an opportunity to express their opinion of the policy and they have done
so. Neither of the two parties
which the issue called into being
has any reason to claim victory.
The Athletic Board was not embarrassed by any censure of the policy
which it had seen fit to adopt; but.
on the other hand, that -policy was
defended only on the ground that
it aid not mean all that it said, and
the vote of confidence which was passed was given only in the belief that the obnoxious eleventh,
twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth
articles of the policy would not be
construed according to the letter.
We have confidence enough in the
man upon whim the objectionable
powers are conferred to believe
that he will not abuse them ; but
we sincerely hope that the Athletic
Board, which has acknowledged
through its representative at the
meeting that the policies are expressed in unfortunate terms, will,
at an early date, take steps to revise them.

I have often gone to a lacrosse
game myself, and wondered how
the center ever lasted through the
two halves. The last game—the
one with Carlisle—carried me beyond the "wonderipg" point. I decided to settle the question once for
all, and to publish the results for
the benefit of the ages! [Hurrah!]
I knew that the track of the center would not be straight by any
means. In fact, I found later that
it was like the crookedness of three
or four shafts of lightning and several shooting stars linked together.
I determined to reckon the distance
by half lengths of the field. The
half length was the best unit of
measurement, because the center
starts from the middle of the field.
Of course, each separate half length
had to be estimated, but on the
whole I did it carefully, and the results should be reasonably correct.
I watched both the Indian and
Hopkins centers., The . outcome of
the count astonished me. First Half—Hopkins center ran
717
2 (half lengths of field). Indian center ran 80 (half lengths of
field).
Second Half—Hopkins center ran
70 (half lengths of field). Indian
centers—they had three—(90 half
lengths of field).
Whole Game—Hopkins center,
14.072 (half lengths of field). Indian centers, 170 (half lengths of
field).
A half length of the field is 65
yards. Therefore, the Hopkins center ran 14072x65=9,13272 yards,
or 5 miles and 33272 yards (that is,
about 575 miles).
The Indian centers ran 170x65.7--11,050 yards, or 6 miles and 490
yards (that is, about 67. miles).
Me for the trolley car!
Yours sincerely,
MATHEMATICUS INSPIRATICUS.
April 20, 1912.
I have long promised myself the
pleasure of writing and offering to
THF, NEWS-LETTER a sort of scientific study of athletics at Johns
Hopkins from the standpoint of the
"dub," in which I should point out
just how little chance the unmuscular undergraduate has of getting
ally fun and exercise out of our
fine athletic equipments:. and in
which I should perhaps offer a few
simple ideas, such as will suggest
themselves to anyone, as to what
great things enthusiastic leadership
could do toward making our athletics help those vtho need help
most. I live in hope of seeing the
tinie when our athletic policy will
be expressed in one golden phrase:
"Every Hopkins man using Homewood Field."
Granted that this is my viewpoint, as it is that of many other
students and alumni, you can easily
see why we are inclined to rage at
this other athletic policy of recent
date. At a time when the best opportunity offers itself for an effort
to get the grandstand athlete down
on the field and track, and to give
his lungs better exercise than yelling for his favored mates, at -just
this time our athletics are to be

5
still more commercialized, dictators
are appointed, some folks mustn't
manage and some must—the Johns
Hopkins Athletic Company (Ltd.)
is incorporated!
We don't need new bosses, better
bosses, or more bosses; we need
somebody with enthusiasm and a
vision, who can get everybody,
muscles or no muscles, impatient to
go to Homewood of an afternoon,
to enjoy an hour or two of sport
under the Black and Blue. He
will be harder to find than .a new
president. Until he conies student
management of student activities is
the only thing which can keep us
out of the slough of Athletic indifference.
GEORGE W. CORNER, 3d, '09.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 29, 1912.

Rhodes Scholarships.
The announcement has recently
reached the University that the
next examinations for the Rhodes
Scholarship will be held here in October, 1912. Two scholarships are
awarded to residents of Maryland,
or students in the state, and are for
three years' residence at Oxford
University. Their value is $1,5oo
per year. The requirements for
eligibility are that a man must be
above 19 and under 25 years old.
He must have finished his sophomore year in college, and he must
be unmarried.
The Rhodes Scholarship examinations are not competitive, but
qualifying, for the award is not
made upon scholarship alone. The
papers set are the regular Oxford
entrance requirements, or "Responsiors," and include arithmetic,
elementary geometry or algebra, elementary Latin and elementary
Greek. A special rule is made that
A:merican students may be eligible
for the scholarship without taking
the Greek examination, but if
awarded the scholarship, they must
study Greek before they are able to
enter Oxford University.
When the candidates have passed
the qualifying . examinations and
award is made upon the basis of
general scholarship one-third, of
athletic ability one-third, and of
general character one-third,

Swarthmore Game Next Saturday.

The annual game of lacrosse between Hopkins and Swarthmore,
which for the past four years has
decided the championship of the
southern division of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League, will be
played at Homewood on Saturday.
This game will be in addition to the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate championships.
